title: Sharif of Mecca
text:
The Sharif of Mecca () or Hejaz () was the title of the leader of the <a href="Sharifate%20of%20Mecca">Sharifate of Mecca</a>, traditional steward of the holy cities of <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a> and <a href="Medina">Medina</a> and the surrounding <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>. The term "<a href="sharif">sharif</a>" is Arabic for "noble", "highborn", and is used to describe the descendants of Prophet <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>'s grandson <a href="al-Hassan%20ibn%20Ali">al-Hassan ibn Ali</a>.
The Sharif was charged with protecting the cities and their environs and ensuring the safety of pilgrims performing the <a href="Hajj">Hajj</a>. The title is sometimes spelled Sheriff or Sherif, with the latter variant used, for example, by <a href="T.%20E.%20Lawrence">T. E. Lawrence</a> in "<a href="Seven%20Pillars%20of%20Wisdom">Seven Pillars of Wisdom</a>".
The office of the Sharifate of Mecca dates back to the late <a href="Abbasid">Abbasid</a> era. Until 1200, the Sharifate was held by a member of the Hawashim clan, not to be confused with the larger clan of <a href="Banu%20Hashim">Banu Hashim</a> from which all Sharifs claim descent. Descendants of the Banu Hashim continued to hold the position until the 20th century on behalf of various Muslim powers including the <a href="Ayyubid%20dynasty">Ayyubids</a> and the <a href="Mamluk">Mamluk</a>s. In 1517, the Sharif acknowledged the supremacy of the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="Caliph">Caliph</a>, but maintained a great degree of local autonomy. During the Ottoman era, the Sharifate expanded its authority northwards to include <a href="Medina">Medina</a>, and southwards to the frontiers of <a href="%27Asir">'Asir</a>, and regularly raided <a href="Nejd">Nejd</a>.
The Sharifate came to an end shortly after the reign of <a href="Hussein%20bin%20Ali%2C%20Sharif%20of%20Mecca">Hussein bin Ali</a>, who ruled from 1908, who rebelled against the Ottoman rule during the <a href="Arab%20Revolt">Arab Revolt</a> of 1916. After the defeat of the Ottoman Empire in 1918 and its <a href="Dissolution%20of%20the%20Ottoman%20Empire">subsequent dissolution</a> in 1923, Hussein <a href="Sharifian%20Caliphate">declared himself Caliph</a>. The British granted control over the newly formed states of <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="Emirate%20of%20Transjordan">Transjordan</a> to his sons <a href="Faisal%20I%20of%20Iraq">Faisal</a> and <a href="Abdullah%20I%20of%20Jordan">Abdullah</a>. In 1924, however, in the face of increasing attacks by <a href="Ibn%20Saud%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">Ibn Saud</a>, Hussein abdicated his political titles to his eldest son, <a href="Ali%20of%20Hejaz">Ali bin Hussein</a>, who was to become the last Grand Sharif. At the end of 1925, Ibn Saud conquered the <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> and expelled the Hashemites. The <a href="House%20of%20Saud">House of Saud</a> has ruled the holy cities and overseen the <a href="Hajj">Hajj</a> since that time.<ref name="Ibn Saud reign of Hejaz – http://www.saudinf.com"></ref>
